>It's not falsifiable though, same as yogachara, same as nagarjuna
So? Metaphysics in general isn't usually falsifiable, this is not news. You can still argue against or for something without being able to directly falsify it. Speaking about consciousness alone can be seen as more of an epistemological matter and not metaphysical, but even here the Advaita position is not falsifiable..... because consciousness is exactly as they say it is and so nobody is able to come up with any solid evidence to the contrary.

Metaphysical claims about ultimate reality being Brahman or empty or mind-only etc are not falsifiable but several of Nagarjuna's arguments are falsifiable and have been falsified already. Nagarjuna claims to refute other non-Shunyavadin views and thereby indirectly justify Shunyavada but various articles and books have already been published (Emptiness Appraised, Buddhist Illogic, Richard's Robinson's essay etc) that identify various logical fallacies and errors that he makes in the MMK. These fallacies undermine his whole enterprise and derail any attempt to claim that he refuted all non-Madhyamaka views. So, in that sense his arguments and his attempted justification of Shunyavada have been falsified, even if Shunyavada as a metaphysical view of reality remains a hypothetical that has not been falsified.

>Can someone explain to me what is the original divide between Advaita Vedanta and Buddhism?

Buddhist believe the ultimate reality is sunyata (emptiness) and through this emptiness, everything in the universe is interconnected and dependent on each other through cause and effect (karma). Because of impermanence and emptiness being the ultimate reality, there is no self (anatma).

Vedanta believe ultimate reality is Brahman, that Brahma exists in everything in the universe and that everyone is one through Brahma. Brahma is the true self (anattā).

"valokitesvara Bodhisattva, doing deep prajna paramita,
Clearly saw emptiness of all the five conditions,
Thus completely relieving misfortune and pain,
O Shariputra, form is no other than emptiness, emptiness no other than form;
Form is exactly emptiness, emptiness exactly form;
Sensation, conception, discrimination, awareness are likewise like this.
O Shariputra, all dharmas are forms of emptiness, not born, not destroyed;
Not stained, not pure, without loss, without gain;
So in emptiness there is no form, no sensation, conception, discrimination, awareness;
No eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, mind;
No color, sound, smell, taste, touch, phenomena;
No realm of sight . . . no realm of consciousness;
No ignorance and no end to ignorance . . .
No old age and death, and no end to old age and death;
No suffering, no cause of suffering, no extinguishing, no path;
No wisdom and no gain. No gain and thus

>>21402365
i imagine, like most people who say they can't read, you mean that you can't focus.

it's just a matter of persistence. read for as long as you can, doesn't matter if you don't understand the text or how far you manage to get into it. just stop when you get too fatigued. do this for a number of days (it will only take 2-3 days) and you will begin to make satisfying progress through the book you intend to read.

once you do this, you're a reader. you can focus your effort on a book over the course of days and weeks until it's finished and you just repeat and exercise this faculty. if you stop reading for a time, do it all over again. it probably won't be as difficult as the first time you do it.

>>21402426
People here in recent years like to meme that 4chan and the old Internet in general always had lax moderation and was some heaven of free speech but the truth of the matter is that the best forums used to have strict moderation. The difference is that the old Internet moderated to gatekeep their communities and keep the quality of posts up, if you didn't like a forums moderation policy you could just find another place that suited your tastes. With modern social media and the death of the forum all of that has changed so you have sites like Facebook and Twitter (pre-musk) moderating themselves to be advertiser friendly and to prioritise content that maximises engagement while users whine about free speech absolutism and how these sites should let them say or do anything. The Internet was a much better place when it was a bunch of smaller communities rather than a few big ones and this fundamental change in how we engage with the internet has also affected 4chan, one of the last holdouts of the old Web.

Why do you think Marx studied bourgeois philosophy and political economy so deeply? He developed and built on it; he didn't discard and ignore it. If philosophy is a society's attempt to understand its own time in thought, then it will contain intense and abstract condensations of the contradictions and problems in that society. The subject-object distinction Kant explores can't be willed away on the basis of its being 'bourgeois', because it's part of our social practice and our deep cultural models. (And anyway, what's to say it wouldn't reappear in some other form in some other, future society?)

I posted this a few months ago but I've reworked it heavily with feedback I got from an anon

I looked on a gravestone white and withered;
No epitaph inscribed the mildewed rock—
Laid on an untamed patch of sun-kissed grass,
Hidden in a field of clement flock.
In the grazing a solemn sheep bowed his head low
When suddenly I heard a caw—the coming of a crow.

It perched upon a gargoyle’s snout
Whose granite gaze once mocked the feeble stone
And it let out a magnificent cry—
A touching eulogy to him unknown.
I brushed aside the overgrown fern and weed:
Seaton Morris, I remarked, the stone did read.

At first there was pity, then there was grief,
That Seaton’s life-story remained unsaid.
But in this thought, I found a comfort, too.
If life is wholly lived so what if death be wholly dead.
In cemeteries potted tulips may long wither away,
But on Seaton’s bare tomb this thought shall forever stay.

>I wish Stella Maris was chopped up and plugged into this book in a sensible way though.
I think CM originally tried to do that, basically, but it was all too big and tangled as a single novel.

If you wanted to do it, I think the best shot would be to have Alicia's talks with the Kid in strict order [i.e. Chicago farewell last] followed by her Stella Maris transcripts, all interleaved with Bobby's story in 1980+. You could stick with Alicia's suicide as the very first thing but then go straight to Bobby's dive to the plane. (Starting The Passenger with a prologue and then a chapter, both in italics, was not good, in my opinion. You want to alternate italics & normal.) That way you just have two timelines, alternating. Not sure if you want to end with the last Stella Maris transcript or Bobby's last thoughts.

You would probably want to shrink/compress the Alicia-Kid talks, if you're adding SM. That would be OK with me since they get a bit annoying anyway.

Well CM has several times described SM as a "coda" to TP which suggests he imagines it read afterwards. But I think if you read the two novels several times and ponder them, you won't end up thinking of them like that. You'll end up thinking of them both existing simultaneously.

posts.name: Anonymouṡ
posts.com:
>>21377577
>Very isolating story for me. Chapter X was ridiculously melancholic. One line above all others has stuck with me from this book, trying to understand its meaning.

>“And when they crash through the walls howling?”

Ever since the border trilogy Cormac's books have been saying that Bad Times Are A-Coming. I think he genuinely believes that Western civilization is on the way out and we're going back to a cruder, more savage existence. He uses Mexico (or, more generally, Latin America) as the symbol of what will prevail:

— Cities of the Plain
When Eduardo taunts John Grady at the end, he says, more-or-less, "we [i.e. Mexico] will bury you".

— No Country For Old Men
It's right there in the title. And it's basically all Bell talks about.

— The Counselor
"The slaughter to come is probably beyond our imagining" says Malkina in the final scene. She's the ruthless hunter who is going to inherit the earth, and where's she from? Argentina. The "civilized" USA is going down. The Couselor himself is basically the average smug American normie, and he sleepwalks to destruction. Brad Pitt's character is more aware of how things really are, but this doesn't save him. (What's his name? Westray.)

Malkina is quite up-front with Reiner about this. "When the axe comes through the door, I'll already be gone, you know that?" Very similar to the line you quoted. CM really believes there are violent forces being held at bay which must eventually break through.


In The Passenger, everyone Bobby talks to expresses the same idea:

"The horrors of the past lose their edge, and in the doing they blind us to a world careening towards a darkness beyond the bitterest speculation."
— Sheddan, Chapter V

"Have you looked around lately, Son? What do you think is coming? Christmas?"
— Borman, Chapter VI

"You think his patience is infinite? I think we're probably almost there. I think the odds are on that we'll still be here to see him wet his thumb and lean over and unscrew the sun."
— Jeffrey, Chapter VIII

The difference is that now it's on a cosmic, religious scale, rather than a civilizational one. Alicia is hyper-sensitive to this, so she actually hallucinates demons at the gate, waiting their moment. She sees literally what Cormac himself sees metaphorically. Bobby doesn't see it quite as she does, but in the line you quote, he's remembering what she said and thinking she might be right.

No. It is noticeably different from his other work, but he’s old as shit and hasn’t published in 16 years. What you’re witnessing here on /lit/ is something rare - an author the board is already fixated on has released a new piece of work, and so, consequently, no one is able to tell /lit/ users what to think. posts.name: Anonymouṡ

>>21386300
I read The Passenger the day it came out. I didn't buy Stella Maris, because I asked for it for Christmas, but I finally cracked and downloaded an illegal epub last night. I was planning to read just the first two or three chapters but obviously I read the first seven.

Quick initial thoughts:

— Stella Maris is more even in quality than The Passenger, and more disciplined. (It has fewer moments you feel are there just because Cormac wanted to write them). If I were Cormac's editor I would have cut 20-30 pages from TP, but little or nothing from SM.

— The worst of TP is worse than the worst of SM.

— The best of TP is better than the best of SM.

— TP more or less works on its own, but SM doesn't at all. If you could keep only one, it would be TP.

— The project as a whole is a lot more successful than I expected. (That serves me right for having any faith in critics & advance readers. They're all idiots.) CM did a fine job of making a novel (two novels) out of basically un-novelish material.

— Cohen is slightly annoying because he isn't sharp enough. I understood at least half the things Alicia said that he didn't. (Maybe that was Cormac's intention — make Alicia more intelligent than the reader, and Cohen less so. It worked for Arthur Conan Doyle.)

— Alicia is likeable. Her worst habit is constantly saying "I know" when Cohen says "I don't understand". She sounds like a smart-aleck twelve-year-old taking a euphemism/colloquialism literally. She's meant to be a bit like that but not that much. I think Cormac slightly misjudged it.

— The two books should be a single volume, as originally intended. Cut down the Alicia-Kid banter sessions and have the SM transcripts after them, all alternating with Bobby's narrative. Get rid of the duplicate stuff (there isn't much). You would end up with one 550-page novel instead of a 400-page novel with a 200-page appendix. Begin with Alicia's suicide & end with Bobby's last five pages. It would be much better.

What did your brother say?
He kissed me on the cheek and whispered to me that he loved me and that it was all right. And then it was.
And then it was.
Yes. Look. It’s a broken record. I’m doing this for you, not for me. I was given a letter to deliver and told not to read it. And I read it. And I cant unread it. Time’s up.
Oh. Yes. Of course.

I'm beginning to think the letter she describes here is metaphorical. She might be making a literary reference I'm missing.

Perhaps. When he goes back to the clinic for the last time and gets Alicia's stuff she's left him a check for $23,000. That might be enough to survive on for a long time in nowhereland in 1980, if he lives rent-free at the windmill. (The owner is some vague friend of the family, and maybe he acts as a sort of caretaker, looking after it?) It's unclear and I don't know why CM was so coy about it.

Tolstoy BTFO the Kind in his book:

>The second way out is Epicureanism. It consists, while knowing the hopelessness of life, in making use meanwhile of the advantages one has, disregarding the dragon and the mice, and licking the honey in the best way, especially if there is much of it within reach. Solomon expresses this way out thus: “Then I commended mirth, because a man hath no better thing under the sun, than to eat, and to drink, and to be merry: and that this should accompany him in his labor the days of his life, which God giveth him under the sun. Therefore eat thy bread with joy and drink thy wine with a merry heart…. Live joyfully with the wife whom thou lovest all the days of the life of thy vanity … for this is thy portion in life and in thy labors which thou takest under the sun…. Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with thy might, for there is not work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor wisdom, in the grave, whither thou goest.”

>That is the way in which the majority of people of our circle make life possible for themselves. Their circumstances furnish them with more of welfare than of hardship, and their moral dullness makes it possible for them to forget that the advantage of their position is accidental, and that not everyone can have a thousand wives and palaces like Solomon, that for everyone who has a thousand wives there are a thousand without a wife, and that for each palace there are a thousand people who have to build it in the sweat of their brows; and that the accident that has today made me a Solomon may tomorrow make me a Solomon’s slave. The dullness of these people’s imagination enables them to forget the things that gave Buddha no peace—the inevitability of sickness, old age, and death, which today or tomorrow will destroy all these pleasures.

>So think and feel the majority of people of our day and our manner of life. The fact that some of these people declare the dullness of their thoughts and imaginations to be a philosophy, which they call Positive, does not remove them, in my opinion, from the ranks of those who, to avoid seeing the question, lick the honey. I could not imitate these people; not having their dullness of imagination I could not artificially produce it in myself. I could not tear my eyes from the mice and the dragon, as no vital man can after he has once seen them.

~Tolstoy, A Confession

>>21403625
The tale of honey, dragon, beast and mice

>There is an Eastern fable, told long ago, of a traveller overtaken on a plain by an enraged beast. Escaping from the beast he gets into a dry well, but sees at the bottom of the well a dragon that has opened its jaws to swallow him. And the unfortunate man, not daring to climb out lest he should be destroyed by the enraged beast, and not daring to leap to the bottom of the well lest he should be eaten by the dragon, seizes s twig growing in a crack in the well and clings to it. His hands are growing weaker and he feels he will soon have to resign himself to the destruction that awaits him above or below, but still he clings on. Then he sees that two mice, a black one and a white one, go regularly round and round the stem of the twig to which he is clinging and gnaw at it. And soon the twig itself will snap and he will fall into the dragon's jaws. The traveller sees this and knows that he will inevitably perish; but while still hanging he looks around, sees some drops of honey on the leaves of the twig, reaches them with his tongue and licks them. So I too clung to the twig of life, knowing that the dragon of death was inevitably awaiting me, ready to tear me to pieces; and I could not understand why I had fallen into such torment. I tried to lick the honey which formerly consoled me, but the honey no longer gave me pleasure, and the white and black mice of day and night gnawed at the branch by which I hung. I saw the dragon clearly and the honey no longer tasted sweet. I only saw the unescapable dragon and mice, and I could not tear my gaze from them. and this is not a fable but the real unanswerable truth intelligible to all. The deception of the joys of life which formerly allayed my terror of the dragon now no longer deceived me. No matter how often I may be told, "You cannot understand the meaning of life so do not think about it, but live," I can no longer do it: I have already done it too long. I cannot now help seeing day and night going round and bringing me to death. That is all I see, for that alone is true. All else is false. The two drops of honey which diverted my eyes from the cruel truth longer than the rest: my love of family, and of writing -- art as I called it -- were no longer sweet to me. "Family"... said I to myself. But my family -- wife and children -- are also human. They are placed just as I am: they must either live in a lie or see the terrible truth. Why should they live? Why should I love them, guard them, bring them up, or watch them? That they may come to the despair that I feel, or else be stupid? Loving them, I cannot hide the truth from them: each step in knowledge leads them to the truth. And the truth is death.

Leo Tolstoy, A Confession

>>21394062
Roger Bacon and Robert Grotesste were two Catholic clerics who came up with the methodology of the scientific method during the heyday of Scholasticism, who followed Aristotle's general principles on using specific cases of a phenomena to discover universal truths which could be used to implement said phenomena again. It also saw the likes of Nicholas of Orseme and the Oxford Calculators who then inspired Gallileo to go against the heavy overreliance of Aristotle in Scholasticism 3 centuries later. Science is closely related to Scholasticism, but it is of a different mutated branch which had a healthy reliance on the teachings of Aristotle but in the realm of the natural world. Frankly, it succeded where a lot of theology failed: being succinct and not overrationalizing phenomena. Who cares whether demons were male/female or how many angels can fit on a pin of a nail? Unlike ethical questions related to theology or the broader nature of God in theology, these are just retarded inquiries whose answers don't affect how we should act in this life at all. That's pretty much why science became so successful than most branches of philosophy.

The Tale of honey, dragon, beast and mice

>There is an Eastern fable, told long ago, of a traveller overtaken on a plain by an enraged beast. Escaping from the beast he gets into a dry well, but sees at the bottom of the well a dragon that has opened its jaws to swallow him. And the unfortunate man, not daring to climb out lest he should be destroyed by the enraged beast, and not daring to leap to the bottom of the well lest he should be eaten by the dragon, seizes s twig growing in a crack in the well and clings to it. His hands are growing weaker and he feels he will soon have to resign himself to the destruction that awaits him above or below, but still he clings on. Then he sees that two mice, a black one and a white one, go regularly round and round the stem of the twig to which he is clinging and gnaw at it. And soon the twig itself will snap and he will fall into the dragon's jaws. The traveller sees this and knows that he will inevitably perish; but while still hanging he looks around, sees some drops of honey on the leaves of the twig, reaches them with his tongue and licks them. So I too clung to the twig of life, knowing that the dragon of death was inevitably awaiting me, ready to tear me to pieces; and I could not understand why I had fallen into such torment. I tried to lick the honey which formerly consoled me, but the honey no longer gave me pleasure, and the white and black mice of day and night gnawed at the branch by which I hung. I saw the dragon clearly and the honey no longer tasted sweet. I only saw the unescapable dragon and mice, and I could not tear my gaze from them. and this is not a fable but the real unanswerable truth intelligible to all. The deception of the joys of life which formerly allayed my terror of the dragon now no longer deceived me. No matter how often I may be told, "You cannot understand the meaning of life so do not think about it, but live," I can no longer do it: I have already done it too long. I cannot now help seeing day and night going round and bringing me to death. That is all I see, for that alone is true. All else is false. The two drops of honey which diverted my eyes from the cruel truth longer than the rest: my love of family, and of writing -- art as I called it -- were no longer sweet to me. "Family"... said I to myself. But my family -- wife and children -- are also human. They are placed just as I am: they must either live in a lie or see the terrible truth. Why should they live? Why should I love them, guard them, bring them up, or watch them? That they may come to the despair that I feel, or else be stupid? Loving them, I cannot hide the truth from them: each step in knowledge leads them to the truth. And the truth is death.

Leo Tolstoy, A Confession

Okay, /lit/, I have taken upon a challenge to translate a Serbian poem in its entirety by respecting the structure of verses and the accuracy of the translation but still taking some liberties to make it all fit together as best as it can. I'm about 1/3 through.

God of Mercy! Mighty is your wonder!
Is it thunder or the earth that’s rumbling!
r‘Rather seas have struck upon the mountains?
‘Tis not thunder nor the earth that’s rumbling
Nor the sea is striking at the mountain,
But their treasures have the saints been sharing:
Saint Petar and Saint Nikola, with Saint –
- Jovan and Saint Ilija, and with them,
Saint Pantelija;
Thus reveals her presence Blessed Mary,
Of aghast her face and soaked in sorrow,
The Thunderous Ilija takes notice, asking:
“O, our sister, Holy Blessed Mary,
“What colossal burden has befell thee,
“Such it wrights upon your cheeks a tempest?”
So speaks forth The Blessed Holy Mary!
“O, my brother, Thunderous Ilija!
“How could I prevent myself from weeping,
“If I’m trav’lin back from Indian land,
“The Indian land, the accursed land?
“Throughout that land lawlessness runs rampant:
“The young one respect doth not the older,
“Doth the child not listen to the parent;
“His own kin the parent layeth waste on
“Wretched be their dignity and honor
“’While the truthful talk with God awaits them,
“Godfather sends godfather to courtroom,
“And seeks in turn false witnesses to speak,
“Foul and faithless with an unclean spirit,
“Own godfather he schemes out money from
“Church or wedding, which godfather, cares not
“Brother invites brother to a duel
“In-laws fight to shame thir closest blood
“And sister calls her brother nearly naught.

Tell me if I should finish it.

Has there been a single video game on par with the greatest products of literature, music, art, and film that would even put it near this conversation? A few anons have suggested it but nothing comes to mind, aside from Tetris (mainly because of the Tetris effect) which I doubt is what they meant.
>>21398959
They're different mediums entirely. Paintings cannot depict inner lives, only whatever is outwardly shown. This is because fine art is a static medium and we can only read hidden emotions by witnessing continuous changes in a person's behavior, in a compare-contrast way. Literature is a continuous medium, and so it can express what Mona Lisa is thinking and how that changes over time, whereas the painting itself only shows what emotions are on her face in that instant.
I'm paraphrasing but Kierkegaard talks a lot about this in the first half of Either / Or. At one point he uses the metaphor of a thousand pictures being taken every second as a means of expressing inner turmoil, which predicts the invention of film by about 50 years and makes me wonder what he would've thought of that medium.

>>21400913
This. I like film, but the limitation of cinema is that it requires too much. You have to subject yourself to the judgement of multiple people (most of whom are not artists themselves) before you even get to make the film. A writer, composer, or painter could keep making art even without financial success and leave a corpus of work that can be re-discovered and appreciated after their death, but a director can only make so many failures before they're prevented from making more films. At best, cinema sacrifices (or at least minimizes the possibility of) genuine expression for the possibility of a more impressive spectacle. This doesn't, necessarily, make it 'inferior' but it's a flaw that you have to acknowledge.

>>21397450

Dostoevsky uses very subtle paradoxical descriptions (often too subtle to consciously spot unless you’re looking) to create a sense of the uncanny, and an example I give in this thread is the dual description of Raskolnikov’s expression at one point (to give an example from Kafka, who picked up on this technique , a woman is described as “effusive” and “demanding” in the same sentence). Although as I note you won’t see this without the right translations since Garnett for example tries to fix this as it seems nonsensical sometimes. The build up you’re talking about is setting the atmosphere of being inside Raskolnikov’s head *and* heart, to make you experience his world. He is cut off from humanity (his name means schismatic) and at one point it even says he wishes he could cut himself off, right after the girl jumps off the bridge. He is in his head, his thoughts have become more real and meaningful to him than most of reality, leading to him being sometimes unable to distinguish. But once the action gets going it is worth the wait

>>21391668
Letter to Franz Overbeck 5/24/78:
>I gather from your brief allusions that our old friend Nietzsche has been holding himself aloof from you as well. There is no doubt that very striking changes have taken place in him; but anyone who observed him and his psychic spasms years ago could almost be justified in saying that a long-dreaded and not entirely unpredictable catastrophe had now overtaken him. I have retained sufficient friendship for him not to read his book – which I glanced through as I was cutting the pages – and can only wish and hope that he will thank me for it some day.

Letter to Franz Overbeck 10/19/79:
>How could I ever forget this friend of mine who was driven from me so forcefully? Although I constantly had the feeling that, at the time of his association with me, Nietzsche’s life was ruled by a mental spasm, and although it was bound to strike me as odd that this spasm could have produced so spiritually radiant and heart-warming a fire as was manifest in him to the astonishment of all, and although, finally, the ultimate decision which he reached in the inner development of his life filled me with the utmost horror when I saw how intolerable a pressure that spasm was finally causing him – I must no doubt also admit that in the case of so powerful a psychic process it is simply not possible to argue along moral lines and that one’s only response can be a shocked silence.

The concept of Will to Power is an accurate explanation of human motivation
Motivations are goal-oriented and you experience positive motivation when your desires are facilitated; that which facilitates a goal is the means, the means = power

>>21400647
This is where you start to realize all the people watching Moe, Romcoms, etc. were right all along. What's the point of watching a serious anime or reading a manga like Berserk or Kingdom when they're honestly not that great? They're certainly good at what they do so long as you judge them only against other, similar series in their medium, but the moment you take a step back and compare them to something outside that medium, their flaws stand out much more, and they begin to just become so tiresome to trudge through knowing you could've enjoying yourself much more if you had picked up a good novel instead. This is why it's important to focus on what each medium does best, and for anime that isn't Dark Fantasy, that isn't Mystery, and it's definitely not Historical Fiction. It's Slice of Life and Iyashikei; Ecchi, Moe, and Comedy. Let literature be what you read when you want a riveting story, when you want to learn and sometimes even come back with some very wise, immediately applicable life advice. Let anime and manga be where you go to relax, looking for comfort in the benign. That's not to say a book can't comfort you, travel literature is great for that, but in my experience it's been a very different sort of comfort; a sort which again, I wouldn't look for in another medium, but allow it to stand out as being distinct in its function and and in its worth.

>>21401640
Every artform has what it does well, and what it can't do much at all. And some of that is cultural. Weebforms, stuff like anime, manga, and light novels, has a lot of good points, and a lot of faults. The sequential publishing and obscene focus on the visual aspect (manga artists get published mainly on drawing, and writing can be superfluous), means that the literary aspect can be shallow or eventually go to shit more than not. A first act implies a coherent last one. Just look at the 'luminary' that was mentioned itt: Berserk.
Weebshit lends itself to stories that go nowhere or end meaninglessly. And often, to works which are infantile, even when they're serious. It's not capable of making something Faustian in character. Maybe it's because the people who make it are often infantile themselves.
This is why I mainly like stuff like Toradora or Patlabor. It's not high art as literature, but it's suited to the form it's in, which means it can develop sincere pathos.

posts.com:
To Richard Wagner

My wishes reach to you with a limp, You have to forgive me this time, beloved Master. I'm thinking of my bodily instability and weakness, and marvel at your robustness, which lead you to fight your way through the maze of new tasks, difficulties, annoyances, fatigue that came with the last few years; so that I don't even have any right to wish you anything further in that respect. (If I could just learn something from you instead!) When I think of your life, I have always felt the sense of its dramatical course: as if you were such a pure dramatist, that you are always living in that very form and that you could only die with the final act. When everything stresses and storms towards one destination, Chance evades, maybe it is terrified. Everything becomes necessary and iron, with extraordinary emotion: just like I find your expression on the beautiful medallion that I was recently gifted. We other humans are always flickering a bit, so that not even our health remains steady.
Now I want to tell you how I found a strangely beautiful prophecy, that I dearly wanted to send you for your birthday.
It says:

(Hölderlin's Gesang des Deutschen, with three lines in cursive, that paint Wagner as the German ideal genius that has yet to come)

All that says poor Hölderlin, who didn't share my luck and who could only guess, what we would venture to see.
Truly, beloved Master, to write to you at your birthday always means: to wish fortune and health to u s, so we would be able to witness Y o u. Because, I must say: it's the "being sick" and the egoism that hides in sickness, that leads them to think of themselves, while the genius, in the immensity of his health, always thinks of others, instinctively blessing and healing anything his hand touches. "Every sick man is a wretch", I recently read; and who can count man's sicknesses! On your journeys in Germany you surely heard a lot, e.f. about the common illness of "Hartmannianism".

Farewell, Dear Master,
and unlike us, stay in good health!
Loyally devoted, your Friedrich Nietzsche

>>21402122
>the turn away from Paganism and non-constitutionalism to Schopenhauerian, all-compassionate faux-christian herd mentality, which is the significant aspect of Wagner that lived on
This isn't quite true. Nietzsche regarded the 'strongest period' of Wagner's life as when he was composing the second half of the Ring during the Franco-Prussian War. He had already long accepted Schopenhauer and a Christian cultural identity by then. It was only during the writing and composing of Parsifal that Wagner took a more extreme Christian approach. It's a very late development, and not at all where Wagner's largest influence comes from or is most famous for. But he never turned away from his Paganism or critique of the state, rather than just developed new focuses. Wagner himself stated in the late 1870s that the Zurich writings were his central works, and it is to this philosophy that, like Nietzsche, the modernists were influenced by and is most characteristic of Wagner.

>It took time for Wagner to integrate his theoretical views into his artistic practice.
Wagner's theoretical views were centred around whatever he was currently composing. When he started on a work his world would become completely absorbed in it, and his writings at the time would reflect this. There's no theoretical lagging behind the artistic in Wagner. In fact Wagner's prose works at the time of finishing the Ring laid the basis for the Dionysianism in TBOT, which appear after his very renunciatory Meistersinger. So it is clear Parsifal represented a new development. To the Wagner prior to this Nietzsche always remained devoted. As Furtwangler writes:

'Isn't there, as it were, a different worldview in every Wagnerian work? The worldliness of Siegfried, the Christianity of Parsifal, the consecration of the night in Tristan, the day world of the Mastersingers, the dualism of Tannhauser, the monism of Lohengrin - where is the real Wagner?'

'Wagner believes in the particular picture he creates, to the point of complete self-renunciation, and yet he knows: it is only a picture, it is only part of the world, it is only seen from one side.'

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Evola and Guenon often use an analogy from Aristotle's four types of causes to demonstrate what they mean by this. In Aristotle there are the material, the efficient, the formal, and the final cause. Every thing that exists or has come into existence has all four. The material is the substrate or components from which the thing is assembled. The efficient cause is the actual physical action in the world, taking place in time, that sets it in motion. This can be interpreted a bit loosely: If you roll clay into a ball, then the initial unformed clay is the material cause, but you yourself (specifically, your actions in time and space in relation to the clay) are the efficient cause of its coming to take the form you want.

But this is still an insufficient account of the how and why of the clay coming to be a ball. To explain that, we need to know WHAT form was "impressed upon" the material BY the efficient cause (the agent, you, who decided to make something come into being where previously there was something else). That's the formal cause. There are two kinds of formal causes. First, subjective ones, in the case of human actions like making clay into a ball or a unicorn or whatever else. In these cases, the form is simply a subjective mental image that the agent applies to the clay until it is formed. Second, objective ones, as natural objects or natural "kinds" are said to have their own concept as their form (in Aristotelian or Platonic realism). Thus there is no Aristotelian universal of "a barn" but there is a really existing concept of any natural form of being, as evidenced by the fact that is capable of imposing stable forms on matter. The most obvious example being the different species of animals.

But we still need to know WHY the agent chose to do this at all. That's the final cause, final in the sense of the "end" that was sought in acting. The final cause is the "for the sake of which" that underlies the whole coming-to-be of the thing. In the subjective case, this is the agent's overriding intent: "I want to make a ball BECAUSE ..." In the objective case, it is the natural "tendency toward perfection," what will later be called the nisus formativus (formative force) or Lebenskraft (life-power) underlying the organism's coming-to-be-what-it-is, imposing-and-maintaining-one's-own-form.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21402152
In the Aristotelian system, these causes are all necessary to explain anything:
>What is it made from? What materials does it "require" to "take up into itself" and become its form? (material cause)
>Conversely, what form is being applied to these materials? (formal cause)
>What concrete agents or forces are being applied, in the world, in real time and space, to move the matter into the places corresponding to its perfected form? (efficient cause)
>Why does this happen at all? Why are the forces doing what they do?
The formal cause is analogous to a Platonic idea, but the final cause is necessary to explain WHY the ideas interact with unformed matter at all. If there is no explanation of this, then we could envision a world in which there are "virtual" immortal forms, and unformed matter, but the two don't interact. There needs to be something driving the process of accommodation between form and matter.

In the subjective case, this something is the intention of the actor, as we mentioned. You made the clay ball BECAUSE someone asked you to, you sell them, etc. The virtual form, the indifferent matter, and the necessary movements of the sculpting hands all came together BECAUSE an invisible, overriding purpose "held" or "bound" them all together until the process was complete.

In the objective case, we obviously can't appeal to an individual actor shaping everything. But we can do something interesting. Go back to the subjective case and ask why any individual agent ever does anything. Boil down every reason a subjective agent might have for making or doing anything, and all will have one thing in common: They all are for the sake of some GOOD. No action is indifferent. There is always a "better" being sought. It is better to have a clay ball, because it's better to sell a clay ball, because it's better to have money, because it's better to have the things money can buy, because it's better to live well and feel pleasure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21402160
Plato and Aristotle extrapolate this to the objective case and see "betterness," "goodness," value, as ontologically real features of reality. The "why" of "why does anything strive 'up and away from' its most entropicically neutral state, why do things continuously put in 'effort' and organize this 'effort' on recalcitrant matter, to become virtual forms? Why does the world strive for form?" is answered by saying that it's for basically the same reason as in the subjective case: the world ITSELF is makes and re-makes itself continuously, continuously approximates "strives" for form and perfection of form, in all its individual parts and as a whole, "for the sake of" the better, the Good. It is simply more Good, more perfect, to have form, than not to have form, thus it is an in-built tendency of all matter to strive for form. This explains how the indifferent, eternal, but in themselves virtual ideas or universals, and the indifferent, recalcitrant "dead" matter continuously come together to make the differentiated, formalized, gradated world we see around us, instead of just a soup of gray matter or base particles.

Everything seeks its own perfection, any "grade" of being is always striving and aiming upward because more and higher form is always "better." Matter strives to be incorporated into organisms, and each successive grade or "soul" of organic life (plant, animal, rational) strives to reach its own perfection in the higher grade. The highest grade of being is only possible in man, who is constantly called toward his own perfect formalization via the perfect actualization of his full potential, which is in contemplation, the activity of his rational soul. Contemplation (theoria) is the highest activity possible in the cosmos, literally divine because it's all God does, and thus humans at their highest peak (as philosophers) can participate in the divine activity, which will then sublate their lower functions (their merely stochastic material parts, their merely appetitive plant soul, their merely libidinal animal soul) and create (for brief moments of pure bliss or ataraxia) a state of almost divine perfection in man, as he contemplates "the whole" of things by bringing his contemplation to perfect transparent adequacy to it. But if the parts of the whole cosmos are mediately good (all striving to be better), then the Whole must be the Good in its most coherent and harmonious aspect, so pure contemplation is also an effectively immanent mystical vision of the Good, including oneself as part of this whole.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21402163
In Aristotle's system, the ultimate perfection that everything seeks, even contemplation itself, is a modification of Plato's Good, the "Good itself," which is God, which is the peak of the cosmic hierarchy, the so-called "Great Chain of Being" (A.O. Lovejoy). This being is necessary because if the whole system is "striving FOR," striving TOWARD something, that "something" must exist. But because direct action of any kind, efficient causation, is inferior to contemplation and realization of the Good, this highest being logically cannot involve any efficient causation at all, nor can it involve matter, because the essence of matter is "lacking in form" i.e. lacking in perfection - matter exists solely to continuously strive toward form, and striving is "for the better." So logically speaking the highest Being cannot either act, because then it would lack something (it would be doing something "for the better," meaning it is not already the best), and it cannot involve any matter, because materiality is by definition a state or grade of imperfection.

The solution then is that God is contemplation itself. But contemplation is "of" something. So God is contemplation contemplating itself: though thinking itself. This is the Platonic Good or One elevated to the final cause of the whole universe. You strive and work to make a clay ball, because you want to feel pleasure (because pleasure is good); the universe continuously strives to "make" its constituent components because they also strive "toward" the ultimate good, which is the state of pure contemplation.

Thus God is both immanent to the world - i.e., God is not a transcendent creator who is fundamentally distinct from the world's visible categories (since man can also, at his absolute peak of potential, participate in contemplation, which is the essence of God) - and transcendent to the world, insofar as God does not act upon any existing thing in any way directly (through efficient causation or through any materiality). Instead, God "acts without acting" by being always present as the center or peak of the whole cosmic system, a system whose very essence is striving toward God, always tending to its own perfection.

>>21402169
That is what Guenon and Evola both use as an analogy for how you should act upon your environment: Be a local version of a "peak of perfection" or purified being that causes the matter and actions of those around you to tend toward their own form and perfection. Evola especially likes the Taoist idea of wei wu wei, action of non-action or "acting not-acting." Traditionalists are obsessed with cosmicizing "centers," "peaks," etc. for the same reason. The aristocrat doesn't get down in the muck of matter and start sloshing matter around with the other unformed or barely-formed muck beings. The aristocrat presents himself as a living model of the instantiation of form and the higher possibilities of formalized matter. He thus becomes LIKE a form, himself, in a local way, vis-à-vis the "matter" (unformed social and cultural systems, dissolute people) around him. His ideal is then to create an aristocratic nucleus, an elite, and then a culture, and eventually even a nation guided by that culture (which is guided by its elite), which can perform the same function for the surrounding "matter" at each successive grade. An elite person shows others how to perfect themselves; a group of perfected elites shows a culture how to perfect itself; a culture leads a nation in the same way, and then that nation can be a model to nations which are in deep states of dissolution and sunkenness in materiality or mere "quantity" (Guenon).

>>21402169
>So logically speaking the highest Being cannot either act,
Act and change are not synonymous. What you are suggesting is that the perfect being cannot change, which is correct (change is a function of potency and act rather than act taken by itself). There is no reason it cannot act so long as it doesn't involve change of itself. The prime mover is said to be pure act (actus purus), not because it changes but because it is that which provides substance to everything through its act.
>and it cannot involve any matter, because materiality is by definition a state or grade of imperfection.
This is again equivalent to stating that it does not possess potency. Matter is a specific kind of passive potency, so the broader way of phrasing this is by saying that it doesn't possess any passive potencies, which would exclude the God from the category of immaterial beings, as well as material beings, because God is being in itself, ie being without the possibility of being something else.
>The solution then is that God is contemplation itself.
The Divine Intellect is self-contemplation. I'm not sure it would be right to equate it with God as such, Aristotle doesn't seem to do so obviously.

it's objectively morally wrong, because it almost always goes against the will of the creator or owner of the intellectual property—i.e: if you were to ask the publisher or author whether you could download it without going through Barnes and Nobel + Kobo or whatever horrible hideous fiasco they're trying to foist on modern man, the publisher would obviously say no...

Publishers don't do what they do because it's fun, but to make a livelihood. That said, even if you were not to impact their bottom line at all, it would still be morally wrong, because the publisher has signed a binding contract with the author which gives them the rights to make money off of their work (in exchange for publishing it, doing all that a publisher does, etc.)

Now I don't know if such contracts have a loophole which entails that the author themselves can distribute their works to those who ask.

But even if there was such a loophole, it's wrong to take from a stranger with the presumption that they'll be ok with it.

what really freaks me out is there's this like genius level autist on Christian/Catholic substack who hosts a massive repository of pirated books, and he fails or refuses to see that what he is doing is morally wrong. I wouldn't say it's a grave matter, but it's morally wrong, intrinsically, and that's pretty fucking obvious.

That said, I pirate books, but my soul is in the dumps in various ways... I guess it's hypocrisy in me? I don't know. Maybe consequentialism is true?

After all, it's a question of laws... and questions of laws/political things are amenable to consquentialism, even on the stodgiest trad picture. Look at Aquinas permitting prostitution so that graver evils would not ensue.

So maybe pirating ought to be legal so that graver evils (physical theft) does not ensue...

This line of thought being so seemingly unrealistically permissive is what motivates me to kick the whole issue up to the level of actual moral acts... but in lieu of some kind of "nature" which I can draw from, I resort to (perhaps a secular?) voluntarism, in which the will is posited as the ultimate agent of things..

We don't accept this move in sexuality (consent does not make any sexual behavior good, on the Catholic picture), but perhaps the interchange of intangible goods is so much less important that we're allowed to do it?

Thoughts? THOUGHTS? FEELINGS??

>>21402498
Ryan Reaves has a good 2 part video on him.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xri0AMiAKIo

Before you start look up what a summa is and how to read one. A summa is a type of debate writing from the Middle Ages and is meant to be read like an encyclopedia you don't need to read it from cover to cover. Just look things up that seem interesting to you. Personally, I would not waste your time with "A Shorter Summa" from the op. The editor deliberately didn't put in theological stuff to appeal more to non-religious people so it's all "How do we know that we know?" philosophical stuff which isn't too interesting to me. Also if you remove the cliff notes it is only about 70 pages. I would just get the full summa and dive in. Reading the summa you can tell St Thomas is insanely smart often times he'll come up with a counter argument that's so good it changes your mind and then you read his response and it changes your mind back. Very cool book and written in a format that you don't usually get to experience.

"Intellectual property" isn't property. You can't own words. You can't own ideas. It would obviously be wrong to pass off something as your own, because that would be lying, but it wouldn't be theft.
Digital "piracy" is illegal, not because it's morally wrong on an individual level, but because making it illegal ensures that creators (inventors, authors, etc.) can make money off their work, which gives them more motivation to create, which is good for society. Law isn't about the enforcement of morality, but the advancement of common good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been with /lit/ through its many ups and downs but I've always loved the board. Whenever I see people whining about how bad it is, aside from particularly bad periods with an obvious problem like spammers, it's usually political fags or butters whining about how their political opponents post too much. /lit/ sucks in a lot of ways and I wish a hard core of posters would dedicate itself to bookposting and keeping bookthreads bumped and living, even if it seems thankless and like they will be drowned out by para-book/culture wars shitposting if they falter for even a moment. But when threads are good they're good.

There is simply no substitute for being able to talk with a bunch of fairly smart/autistic guys, who can all maintain a level head and keep talking normally even while discussing difficult/obscure topics, all while people are calling eachother faggots and retards, and saying offensive or unusual or contrarian things. Any other social media site is filled with whiny faggots who need you to soften your language like you're talking to a testy woman, and file a brief with the court 6 months in advance before saying something mildly unusual. You can almost feel normies jamming on the brakes any time you say something unexpected, even if it's benign. If it's not normies, it's the tyrannical kind of autist that prefers overmoderated communities and cliques with endless drama.

/lit/ is one of the few places left where you can just talk to men the way men used to be, where the worst case scenario is they go "lol fuck off mate you're a retard" and that's that. Makes for the best jokes and banter. /lit/ probably has the same spirit as a gentleman's club back in the day, the only thing it lacks is a bit more substance because every individual poster, on average, is a disaffected young male who doesn't read much. The average investment level of any given post in an X thread is "just getting into X."

But that in itself is charming and nice compared to other places, where everyone is so smug and complacent. Elsewhere, it's smug complacent mediocrities and midwits acting like bigshots. Every 1 point of status they have, they act 10 points of up their own ass about it. And everyone excuses laziness, assumes and expects laziness as the default. Here, everybody is genuinely eager to learn, admit faults, banter. Everybody says 4chan is just hostile and negative, but this is a board full of jaded young men who actively want to learn things.

Universities spend all their time forcing and begging people to be engaged with pathetic infantilizing gestures, and they get back 1% of what they put in. 4chan puts in "fuck you retard" and gets back a bunch of guys exchanging notes on good books to read about ancient Rome. Places like this used to go down in the history books, I hope /lit/ does some day.

The contemporary right-wing base exists only as a reaction to the negative consequences of liberalism weighed against what's left of American/Christian/localist traditionalism. More plainly, contemporary right-wingers are people who were taught one thing by their parents (that was probably very much in vogue when they were taught it) and then came of age into a world where those values are long out of style. Because they are not prepared to abandon those values they pick the party (which is only one of two) that most closely resemble what their values are and ride or die with it.

Because patriotism and American exceptionalism are some of those holdout traditional values this makes for an easy fit despite the fact that the Republican Party, on closer inspection, is in reality a disgusting amalgam that, while paying lip service to the traditionalist crowd, in reality does not substantially support their interests or their values at all. We can characterize the pre-Trump Republican party as primarily being made up of poor/middle class traditionalists on one side and ultra-wealthy businessmen on the other. Due to the fact that the libertarian-leaning lingo of the businessmen uses the same keywords that the poorer party-members have learned to revere (freedom, personal choice, personal responsibility, free markets, low taxes, low government involvement etc) the treachery of the business class is hidden, and they are able to pursue interests that are very much at odds with the poorer classes while making only a few concessions that are useless anyway (gun control, abortion, Christianity).

So to answer the OP, the reason right wing books are cringe is because the Republican platform is incomprehensible and not consistent. There isn't a driving force behind it except to lower labor costs. It's a catch-all for the people that get fucked over by Progressivism.

Also important to note this is why people like Trump get elected, and why the base is so receptive to ideologies that speak to them from a more philosophically-grounded place (Populism, Carl Schmitt's existentialism).

posts.com: The third position and dumb right wing populism is doomed to fail. Let's be honest, we need to address the fundamental questions of political subjectivity and capitalism, before we do anything. If there is a fundamental divide between the right and the left, it is over the question of political subjectivity. The right will succeed - and really, has already succeeded - insofar as it takes a disintegrative and materialist approach to political subjectivity (i.e if it moves beyond things like racialized politics and insipid populism, to a sort of extreme darwinism). The right is in the unique position to identify with the entire ecology, rather than a particular political subject. The left, frankly speaking, cannot do this. It is intrinsically caught up in certain subjectivities, and that's why it will lose. The right should identify with capital itself, against all else. How does the left plan to account for things like labour's substitution driving the creation and proliferation of AI? UBI? Fat chance of that. AI alone makes questions about environmental and demographic collapse manifoldly more complex. It is a fantastic example of the sort of boundary expansion which is absolutely traumatic to the left and right alike. The left basically operates under the basic assumption that capitalism will eat itself, and will be dialectically overcome by some revolutionary subject. But what if capitalism outlasts humanity itself? The ultimate pill is realizing that machinic superintelligence has already secured the legacy of the Anglo-American and East Asian (especially Chinese) civilizations. The right wins insofar as it commits itself to this capitalist jihad. Remember that there is no hope, there is no escape. Capital is war, and war is God.

The Marxist principle of use-value is effectively a servile position (to be useful is to serve a master), whereas the aristocratic critique is sovereign because it sees sacrificial or wasteful expenditure as an end in itself. Marxism, in its exaltation of utility, renders itself an impotent, petit-bourgeois critique of capital In service of “the good” in society, which is still a form of servitude or bondage to something outside of itself.

>>21401672
Listen. The fundamental issue in this conversation is that Bataille’s theory isn’t exclusive to production and objects, but energy itself at an extremely broad sense. For this reason, an act such as non-reproductive sex can be considered a squandering of energy that is ultimately useless.
>But isn’t the use of such an act to gain pleasure?
Already the language gets weird because utility isn’t easily placed into the context of non-reproductive sex. However on this website people probably would ascribe some utility—the social capital that allows one to exit inceldom. Truth is, many things escape purely rational use. Pleasure as a goal is by no means utility, it is a squandering. The theory of rational economic choice, popular at Bataille’s time, would never be able to get us to the existence of drugs. The point if his accursed share is to incorporate this inevitable behavior of humans, where they consume without expecting reciprocation, into a wider system. It isn’t to say such acts are pointless to begin with, making a question like
>but drugs are used to get high and gain pleasure, so isn’t that their utility?
Irrelevant. We chalk up such luxury, which he successfully theorizes and baudrillard continues upon, to pleasure. But it is an epiphenomena that ultimately still needs explanation. The explanation is precisely that the excess of energy produced by the sun (and the irreducible remainder for Baudrillard) ultimately must be expended and cannot always be reinvested back into growth. This area of expenditure is exactly what defines a culture: the non-productive (consumption) they carry out.

For Bataille, the profanation of the sacred is closing off the usual routes through which we squander this excess. The result is destruction: it must be expended and if not done so properly things get violent.

I know that this might be a bit off-topic (no idea who this Bataille person is), but I would like to push back against your defense of rational choice theory.

The core problem with it isn't that it's absolutely false. Rather, it doesn't actually provide very much insight into the nature of political economy. One of the fundamental Marxist gestures is the rejection of the illusion that the value of a commodity can be comprehend in terms of pure hazard, as the contingent interplay of subjects that creates the dynamics of supply and demand. Mainstream economics may be able to formulate patterns about the world, but it is nonetheless locked into the logic of commodity fetishism, unable to recognize labor as the true source of wealth, and then to explain political economy on that basis.

Ultimately, your arguments amount to an assertion that we experience life as individuals and that ethics implies enjoyment, but for our purposes, that is where it stops.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Thought the “thinkers” of 4chan might enjoy this perspective.

Why You’re Christian
Becoming an educated citizen starts with understanding the lineage of your beliefs. For example, look at this iconic line from one of America’s founding documents:

“We hold these truths to be self-evident that all men are created equal.”

This is the most famous sentence in America’s Declaration of Independence. It’s the driving intellectual force behind the nation’s constitutional belief in legal equality. Educated citizens base their commitment to American ideals on it. This commitment shows up in our theories of democracy, in which each citizen has an equal vote, and our justice system, in which all humans are supposedly equal under the law.

But there’s a problem: human equality isn’t self-evident at all.

John Locke, whose intellectual ink is tattooed all over the Declaration of Independence, knew this. His theory of natural rights is based on the idea that God owns us as property. Human equality is self-evident only if you assume, as Locke did, that God has given us the natural rights that modern Americans take for granted. The original Constitution says that our “unalienable rights” are a result not of secular rationalism, but rather an omnipotent God who endows us with those rights. To that end, the pillars of American law rest as much on the Bible as on the writings of Enlightenment thinkers. Even our most “rational” beliefs are downstream of religious thinking.

This creates cognitive dissonance for secular people who advocate for human rights. While they might not realize it, nine times out of ten, they’ve unconsciously inherited a belief in human rights and are unaware of the foundational ideas which underpin that belief. So now, they’re faced with a head-scratching dilemma: one of their central beliefs — human rights — is self-evident only if God says so.

In other words: If you believe in human rights but don’t believe in God, you need a logical explanation for why they’re self-evident.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Human Rights: A Relatively New Idea

History teaches us that until recently, people operated under a very different moral code. In the barbarian world, the weak were exploited by the strong and enslaved by the powerful. Ancient Rome provides an example. Citizens believed that neither the poor nor the weak had intrinsic value, which is why Caesar was able to kill one million Gauls and enslave a million more. It’s also why Roman infants were routinely abandoned like Moses in the baby basket. To the modern mind, these actions are repugnant.

For that, we have to credit Christianity. The historian Tom Holland has called it the “most enduring and influential legacy of the ancient world, and its emergence the single most transformative development in Western history.” Religious or not, every Westerner bathes in the waters of Christian ideology. Those droplets are born from Christ’s insistence that every human is a child of God and the way St. Paul urged people to “welcome one another” across all social and ethnic barriers. Until recently, in Europe, to be human was to be a believer and to be a believer was to be Christian. Yes, we credit the Greeks for shaping our view of the good life. But even they were interpreted through a Christian lens. Aristotle through Aquinas, Plato through St. Augustine.

We are desensitized to Christianity’s influence on Western thought not because it’s irrelevant, but because it’s so all-consuming. Consider this: the coordinates of time and space are both measured in reference to Christ. The year at the top of every calendar denotes the number of years since Christ was born. When it comes to space, “The West” is any place to the West of where Christ was crucified.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Our mainstream notion of human rights is also a byproduct of Christianity. Human rights exist in their modern form because the Bible says that every person is made in the image of God—imago dei. In turn, each person is granted unalienable rights, and those rights can’t be taken away. But the contract breaks down if human beings aren’t special. If humans are in the same category of every other animal, there is no intellectual scaffolding to uphold either human rights or the legal equality of man. Appealing to human rights just because we say so is as baseless as appealing to astrology or the will of Zeus. Even if a group of people can agree on how to treat people in the moment, consensus can change at any moment. Today’s virtues can become tomorrow’s vices. Like a sand castle, the tenets of morality can be destroyed by the tide of public opinion.

Without the word of God, all we have are opinions. Morality and justice are downgraded from indisputable truths to mere preferences and shared fictions. Both of those can change on a whim. In a world of one person’s word against another, the most powerful person will control the moral landscape. This problem is one of the central themes of Dostoyevsky’s writing: in an 1878 letter, he asked why he should live righteously in a world without a god. Assuming that there is no afterlife and that the police wouldn’t catch him after a wrongdoing, he asks: “Why shouldn’t I cut another man’s throat, rob, and steal?”

Today, our answer boils down to human rights. To Dostoevsky’s point, without the hand of God to shape human morality, many people will conclude that the benefits of a righteous life aren’t worth the costs. In theory, we could base our belief in human rights on rationality and the mutual agreement that some actions are better than others. Maybe one day, people will worship the United Nations’ Human Rights charter like they worship the Bible today. Doing so would take us away from the woo-woo of religion and towards the rigor of secular reason, where we can logically discern the differences between good and evil. But in practice, no matter how much we’d like it to be otherwise, an objective and unchanging belief in human rights can be justified by faith and faith alone.

Though the intrinsic worth of every person is a keystone of Western morality, Christianity’s influence has been stripped out of the narrative. At the time of this writing, the Wikipedia page about human rights doesn’t even mention Christianity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Maybe it’s because, as a post-Enlightenment society, we crave scientific explanations for our beliefs. But neither the laws of physics nor the principles of chemistry can serve as a foundation for human rights. In the language of David Hume, science can tell us how the world is, but not how it ought to be. Philosophy can’t save human rights either. Immanuel Kant argued that humans deserve special respect because they are rational creatures, and therefore, ends in themselves. But that argument has problems too. Why should we only respect rational beings? And as individuals, are humans only as worthy as they are rational?

One reason we underestimate how much Christianity has influenced our thinking is that we’ve removed religious education from our schools. The same people who tout the virtues of being well-read skip right past the Bible, the most popular book in human history. To my amazement, I made it through 16 years of schooling without ever reading the Gospels. That thinking continues into adulthood, where we’ll binge-read biographies about some hot new tech CEO while skipping the one about the most important figure in Western history: Jesus Christ.

Recognizing the Influence of Religion

I’m not saying that we should force people to be religious. After all, I’m a tepid non-believer myself. But being secular doesn’t give you a hall pass to ignore your Christian influences. We should study religion not to dogmatically accept faith, but to understand the foundations of our worldview. As we do, we should ask ourselves: “Is Christianity true?” And if you think it’s bogus, then: “Why do I let these ideas influence my worldview so strongly?”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Even humanism, which prides itself on a kind of rationality that can only be achieved without the dogmas of religion, was seeded inside the soil of Christian ideas. Given that, it’s no coincidence that all the biggest international humanist conferences (except one) take place in cities inside of Christian countries: Oxford, London, Oslo, Washington D.C., Brussels, Hannover, London, Mumbai, Boston, Paris, and Amsterdam. If you investigate the intellectual lineage of humanism, you’ll see how it grew out of the seeds of Christ and how they were nurtured with the teachings of the Bible.

Ever since the Enlightenment, the march of intellectual progress has followed the compass of empiricism. Intellectuals in particular have tried to silence religious explanations for the creation of the world, and the decline of religious affiliation shows that their ideas are catching on. Look, I get it. The “Man in the Sky” idea of God seems ancient. Comical, even. Centering your life around a book written 2,000 years ago seems like the antithesis of progress. Even if old ideas tend to stick around because they’re true or useful, embracing all those old Biblical philosophies is lunacy in our fast-changing world. But something about this argument is unsatisfying.

Cafeteria Christianity

Some intellectuals have tried to navigate this conundrum by becoming Cafeteria Christians. It’s like they’re at a hotel buffet, where they can take the foods that look appetizing and reject the rest. Cafeteria Christians want to adopt the most useful parts of the tradition and reject everything else.

This a-la-carte philosophy isn’t new. It’s what Thomas Jefferson did two centuries ago when he wrote the Jefferson Bible. Specifically, he reduced the Bible into a self-help book by removing all the miracles but keeping the sound life advice. The problem is that you can’t pick and choose theology without becoming a slave to intellectual fashions or destroying the integrity of those ideas in the first place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Knowing that, some intellectuals have kept the New Testament intact but embraced a metaphorical interpretation of it. When this “spiritual, but not religious” crowd compliments religion, they do it backhandedly. Religion is a “useful lie,” they say. The argument goes like this: Even if religious ideas aren’t literally true, the world is a safer and more prosperous place when we buy into them. Thus, we should deceive ourselves and become religious even though — wink, wink — it’s false.

They justify this worldview with empirical data. For example, one study found that attending weekly religious services raises people’s happiness as much as moving from the bottom quartile of income to the top. Moreover, doubling their rate of religious attendance raises their income by nine percent. Another study found that the percentage of Americans who rated their mental health as “excellent” fell for everybody except those who attended a religious service in the past week. Under this belief system, religious ideas are worthy not because they’re true, but because they make us happier and more successful. If so, religion is, indeed, the opiate of the masses.

The problem is that you can’t just pick certain ideas from the buffet if you want to be intellectually honest.

Intellectual Honesty

The atheist scholar Christopher Hitchens was once interviewed by a unitarian minister who called herself a “Liberal Christian.” Though she identifies as a Christian, she doesn’t believe Jesus died for her sins. Instead, she reads the scripture metaphorically. Hitchens, who was one of Christianity’s fiercest critics, responded by saying: “I would say that if you don’t believe that Jesus of Nazareth was the Christ and Messiah, and that he rose again from the dead and by his sacrifice our sins are forgiven, you’re really not in any meaningful sense a Christian.”

Echoing Hitchens’ point, Christianity is unique among religions because it has a self-destruct mechanism. The book of I Corinthians says that the truth of Christianity hinges upon the resurrection’s historical reality — meaning that the story of Christ dying on the cross and coming back to life must be literally true. So if you discover that Christ was not raised, you should stop being Christian. End of story. Specifically, the text says: “If Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile… Those also who have fallen asleep in Christ are lost. If only for this life we have hope in Christ, we are of all people most to be pitied.”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Others say that Christ was a brilliant teacher, but not the son of God. Appealing as that argument sounds, C.S. Lewis critiqued this perspective half a century ago. He argued that you can’t accept him as a great moral teacher without also accepting his claim to be God. Since Jesus’ claims were so outlandish, he couldn’t have been just a great moral teacher. You must take a stand. Christ was either the Son of God or a madman. Lewis writes: “You can shut him up for a fool, you can spit at him and kill him as a demon or you can fall at his feet and call him Lord and God, but let us not come with any patronizing nonsense about his being a great human teacher.”

Though I find myself doing it all the time, thinking of religion metaphorically instead of literally is problematic. Christianity, and therefore the moral underpinnings of the West, is long-term stable to the extent that enough people believe in all that Christ claimed to be and the literal truth of his story. Ultimately, a religious affiliation built upon metaphors instead of hard truths is a worldview that’ll crumble under the weight of scrutiny.

The Many Buckets of Faith

I have a confession to make: I’ve spent my entire life in this metaphorical camp. Growing up, I attended a Jewish school where I took 40 minutes of both Hebrew and Biblical studies every day. But as early as elementary school, I thought I was above religious thinking. I “knew” that Moses didn’t actually part the Red Sea and didn’t ascend Mount Sinai to have an actual conversation with God. All that sounded as counterfeit as the tooth fairy. Even as I sang the Torah portion during my Bar Mitzvah to a crowd of a couple hundred friends and family members, I rejected the teachings I was chanting. Only after college did I discover that the ideas I passionately rejected, particularly the Old Testament and the Ten Commandments, were the bedrock of my moral philosophy.

Not just mine, all my friends too — and we didn’t even know it. In retrospect, that’s why we strive to treat disabled people with dignity and it’s why sentences like this one from a government official inspire head-nodding agreement: “A city is measured by how it treats the least of its brothers and sisters. That’s what we all believe, that’s what we’ve grown up believing, and it’s who we are.” We agree with these ideas because Christianity is the invisible frame around modern thought. These moral conclusions are shaped by the Beatitudes where Christ instructs us to bless the poor, the meek, and the persecuted. Until Christ, those blessings were reserved for the rich and powerful.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I call people in this group “Religious Atheists.”

As a member of this tribe, I don’t have a problem with the conclusions. I have a problem with the ignorance caused by the blind dismissal of religion, and the way they mock the assumptions that underpin their worldview. This group of Religious Atheists is the fastest-growing religious group in America. In 2000, almost 70% of Americans considered themselves to be a member of a church, synagogue, or mosque. In just two decades, that number has fallen to below 50%. It’s a group of people who want Christianity without Christ. They want community without communion, the kingdom without the king, and like Thomas Jefferson, morals without miracles.

Again—I’m a member of this group. My worldview rests on two contradictory axioms: I don’t believe in the resurrection of Christ, but I passionately believe in human rights. I’m pulled towards agnosticism because I don’t have enough evidence to be a believer. Deep down, I’ve chosen to remain an agnostic because the existence of God is beyond my comprehension. Asking me about God’s presence is like asking an ant what I should order at In-N-Out Burger. The sentence doesn’t compute. Further, the idea that the son of God was born of a virgin, traveled through contemporary Israel performing miracles, died on a cross, and came back to life seems as bizarre to me today as it did to the Romans two millennia ago. And yet, the intellectual history of Western civilization orbits around this story.

But because of my commitment to human rights, I’m implicitly committed to Christian ideas—or at the very least, a moral philosophy that’s propped up by the Bible. And it’s not just me. American law and culture are thoroughly Christian too. Though I’m closer to an atheist than a believer, I shiver at the nihilistic conclusions of a world without God. One where morality follows intellectual fashion and leaders rule by the cold calculus of Excel spreadsheets. That, in turn, has opened my ears to the truth of Judeo-Christian teachings.

As for my religious odyssey, I’m still not sure where I’ll end up. I know I want to live critically, which starts with an examination of my worldview. I don’t want to follow in the footsteps of my friends, who’ve ignored the influence of religious ideas on the making of the Western Mind, not to mention my teachers, who didn’t stop to investigate the words “self-evident” when they taught the Declaration of Independence.
